docs.snippet: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup....
docs.lead_paragraph: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
docs.abstract: Tiny gulf nation of Qatar, lacking enough young players to form national soccer team, began ambitious program to identify and train talent from Africa as it sought to build credibility as host of 2022 World Cup; Qatar says program is humanitarian venture, though there is some concern country may nationalize some of players (Series: Seeding the Field).

headline.main: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad
headline.print_headline: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad

byline.contributor: Steve Eder reported from Doha, Qatar; Sam Borden from Eupen, Belgium; and Christopher Harress and Jack Williams from New York.
byline.original: By STEVE EDER, SAM BORDEN, CHRISTOPHER HARRESS and JACK WILLIAMS

docs.snippet: Soccer is a hugely important force in the world today, so it is time for the sport to clean up its act....
docs.lead_paragraph: Soccer is a hugely important force in the world today, so it is time for the sport to clean up its act.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends Brazil should be proud after hosting an excellent World Cup, but claims it is past time for FIFA to measure up to the sport it governs; calls on organization to address financial mismanagement, bribery, embezzlement and match-fixing that has been plaguing it; holds Cup also revealed need for tighter concussion rules and the institution of replay challenges to address dubious calls.

headline.main: Cleaning Up After the World Cup
headline.print_headline: Cleaning Up After the World Cup

docs.snippet: The 2014 World Cup was a runaway success, but significant issues like match fixing, player safety and the Cup bidding process need to be confronted....
docs.lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup was a runaway success, but significant issues like match fixing, player safety and the Cup bidding process need to be confronted.
docs.abstract: Sam Borden On Soccer column holds that though 2014 World Cup was a success, significant issues like match fixing, player safety and the Cup bidding process need to be confronted by FIFA.

headline.main: Ugly Reality Intrudes On World Cup’s Glow
headline.print_headline: Ugly Reality Intrudes on World Cup’s Glow

docs.abstract: Pilot Flying J, truck stop company owned by Jimmy Haslam, who controls Cleveland Browns football team, and his brother Tennessee Gov Bill Haslam, agrees to pay $92 million penalty for cheating customers out of promised rebates and discounts.
